question:
How is Swathi related to Namitha?

Statements:

I. Swati's husband is the only son of Namitha's mother.

II. Swati's brother and Namitha's husband are cousins.

RRB ALP 09/08/2018 (Evening)
option_1: Either I or II is sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: II alone is sufficient while I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_3: I alone is sufficient while II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_4: Both I and II are sufficient to answer the question.
solution:
Statement I:

Swati's husband is the only son of Namitha's mother.

This means:

  • Namitha‚Äôs mother has only one son, and that son is Swati‚Äôs husband.
  • So, Namitha is the daughter of the same mother, and hence:
    • Namitha and Swati‚Äôs husband are siblings (Namitha is the sister of Swati‚Äôs husband).
    • Therefore, Swati is Namitha‚Äôs sister-in-law.

This statement alone is sufficient.

Statement II:

Swati‚Äôs brother and Namitha‚Äôs husband are cousins.

This tells us:

  • Swati‚Äôs brother and Namitha‚Äôs husband are cousins.
  • But this doesn't directly establish a clear relationship between Swati and Namitha.
  • They could be related in different ways depending on family structure.

This statement alone is not sufficient.

So, the correct answer is: (c) I alone is sufficient while II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.

question:
How is damini related to Bhola?

Statement:

I. Tika has only one son, Bhola and only one daughter, kamala.

II. Damini is Roma‚Äôs son‚Äôs wife. Kamala is the only daughter of Roma. Meghan is the daughter of Bhola.

NTPC CBT II Level 5 (12/06/2022) Shift 1
option_1: Statement II alone is sufficient, while statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: Statements I alone is sufficient, while II is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_3: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question.
option_4: Statements I or II are not sufficient to answer the question.
solution: https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1752816511050_image001.png

question:
In which year was Dheeraj born?

Statements:

I. Dheeraj at present is 35 years younger to his mother parvati.

II. Dheeraj‚Äôs brother Shan, who was born in 1998 is 45 years younger to his mother parvati.

NTPC CBT II Level 2 (13/06/2022) Shift 1
option_1: I alone is sufficient, while II alone is not sufficient
option_2: Both I and II together are sufficient
option_3: II alone is sufficient, while I alone is not sufficient
option_4: Either I alone or II alone is sufficient
solution:
Statement I:

Dheeraj at present is 35 years younger to his mother Parvati.

This gives us a relationship between Dheeraj's current age and Parvati's current age, but it does not tell us Parvati's age or birth year.

So we can‚Äôt determine Dheeraj's exact age or birth year from this alone.

Statement I alone is NOT sufficient.

Statement II:

Dheeraj‚Äôs brother Shan, who was born in 1998, is 45 years younger than their mother Parvati.

From this, we get:

  • In 1998, Shan was born.
  • That year, Parvati was 45 years older than Shan, so:
    • Parvati‚Äôs age in 1998 = 45
    • Therefore, Parvati‚Äôs year of birth = 1998 ‚àí 45 = 1953

Now, using this, we can find Parvati's current age:

  • Suppose the current year is 2025
  • Parvati‚Äôs age in 2025 = 2025 ‚àí 1953 = 72
  • Now from Statement I: Dheeraj is 35 years younger than Parvati, so:
    • Dheeraj‚Äôs age = 72 ‚àí 35 = 37
    • So, Dheeraj‚Äôs birth year = 2025 ‚àí 37 = 1988

Hence, using both statements together, we can determine Dheeraj‚Äôs birth year.

Correct Answer: (b) Both I and II together are sufficient

question:
In a certain code language ‚Äòpu ma kas‚Äô means ‚Äòwe eat mangoes‚Äô. What is the code of ‚Äòmangoes‚Äô ? Statements:

I. ‚Äòla ti kas‚Äô means ‚Äòwe are graduates‚Äô.

II. ‚Äòhum tup pu‚Äô means ‚Äòthey eat bananas‚Äô.

NTPC CBT II Level 5 (15/06/2022) Shift 3
option_1: Statement I alone is sufficient , while statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: Statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question.
option_3: Statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question.
option_4: Statements II alone is sufficient, while statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
solution:
Statement I:

‚Äòla ti kas‚Äô = ‚Äòwe are graduates‚Äô

  • Common word: we
  • Common code: kas

    So, kas = we

Now in ‚Äòpu ma kas‚Äô = ‚Äòwe eat mangoes‚Äô

  • ‚Äòkas‚Äô = ‚Äòwe‚Äô ‚Üí left with pu, ma = eat, mangoes

    Can‚Äôt tell which is ‚Äòmangoes‚Äô

Statement II:

‚Äòhum tup pu‚Äô = ‚Äòthey eat bananas‚Äô

  • Common word: eat
  • Common code: pu

    So, pu = eat

From earlier:

  • kas = we, pu = eat

    ‚Üí Remaining: ma = mangoes

Now we know mangoes = ma

Final Answer: (c) Statements I and II together are sufficient.

question:
How many workers are there in a factory?

Statements:

I. There are more than 30 but less than 37 workers in the factory.

II. There are more than 34 but less than 41 workers in the factory.

The number of workers in the factory can be divided into two groups in such a manner that each group contains an equal number of workers.

NTPC CBT II Level 5 (15/06/2022) Shift 2
option_1: Statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question
option_2: Statement I alone is sufficient to answer the question
option_3: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question
option_4: Statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question
solution:
Statement I:

Workers are more than 30 but less than 37

So possible values: 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36

Statement II:

Workers are more than 34 but less than 41

So possible values: 35, 36, 37, 38, 39, 40

Combining I and II:

Common values between both statements = 35 and 36

Also, we are told:

Workers can be divided into two equal groups

So, the number must be even.

Among 35 and 36, only 36 is even.

So, 36 is the only possible number of workers

Final Answer: (c) Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question.

question:
Who ranked first in the class?

Statements:

I. Sreeja ranked 2nd

II. Aman ranked one rank below Sreeja.

III. Rohit ranked better than Aman.

NTPC CBT II Level 2 (16/06/2022) Shift 3
option_1: Each statement I,II and III alone is sufficient.
option_2: All statements I,II and III together are sufficient.
option_3: Statement II alone is sufficient, while Statement III alone is not sufficient.
option_4: Statement I alone is sufficient, while Statement II alone is not sufficient.
solution:
Statement I:

Sreeja ranked 2nd

‚Üí So someone else is 1st.

We don‚Äôt know who. Not sufficient.

Statement II:

Aman ranked one rank below Sreeja

‚Üí If we don‚Äôt know Sreeja‚Äôs rank, we can‚Äôt say Aman‚Äôs rank.

Alone, not sufficient.

Statement III:

Rohit ranked better than Aman

‚Üí We don‚Äôt know Aman‚Äôs rank.

Alone, not sufficient.

Now combine all three:

  • From I: Sreeja is 2nd
  • From II: Aman is 3rd
  • From III: Rohit ranked better than Aman ‚Üí So Rohit is either 1st or 2nd

But Sreeja is 2nd ‚Üí So Rohit must be 1st

Final Answer: (b) All statements I, II and III together are sufficient.

question:
Who is the shortest among A, B, C, D and E ?

Statements:

I. A is taller than E but shorter than D.

II. B is shorter than C but taller than E.

III. D is taller than C and A is taller than B.

NTPC CBT - I 04/01/2021 (Evening)
option_1: Statements I and II together are sufficient.
option_2: Statements I and III together are sufficient.
option_3: Statements I, II and III are insufiicient.
option_4: Statements I, II and III are sufficient.
solution:
Statement I:

A is taller than E but shorter than D

‚Üí D > A > E

Statement II:

B is shorter than C but taller than E

‚Üí C > B > E

Statement III:

D is taller than C and A is taller than B

‚Üí D > C

‚Üí A > B

Now Combine All Three:

‚Üí D > C > A > B > E

So, the shortest is E

Final Answer: (d) Statements I, II and III are sufficient.

question:
When is Yuvi‚Äôs wedding anniversary?

Statements:

On 7th day of a month.

2. The month has 29 days only in a leap year.

NTPC CBT - I 29/12/2020 (Morning)
option_1: Both statement 1 and statement 2 are sufficient independently
option_2: Only statement 1 is sufficient but statement 2 is not sufficient
option_3: Both statements 1 and statement 2 are sufficient together
option_4: Only statement 2 is sufficient but statement 1 is not sufficient
solution:
Statement 1:

"On 7th day of a month."

‚Üí Only gives day (7th), not the month

Not sufficient

Statement 2:

"The month has 29 days only in a leap year."

‚Üí This clearly refers to February, which has 29 days only in leap years.

‚Üí But no specific day is mentioned.

Not sufficient

Now Combine Both:

  • From Statement 1: Day = 7
  • From Statement 2: Month = February

So, Yuvi‚Äôs anniversary = 7th February

Final Answer: Both statements 1 and 2 are sufficient together

question:
Find the ratio of boys and girls in the class?

Statement:

I) There are 20 boys in the class.

II) The ratio of the number of girls and students in the whole class is 3 : 7.

ALP Tier II 21/01/2019 (Morning)
option_1: Statement alone is sufficient, while Statement alone is not sufficient.
option_2: Either statement I or statement II is sufficient
option_3: statement I alone is sufficient, while statement alone is not enough.
option_4: Neither statement I nor is statement II sufficient.
solution:
Statement I gives only the number of boys (20), but nothing about girls. So, it is not sufficient alone.

Statement II gives the ratio of girls to total students as 3:7. From this, the number of boys can be found as 4 parts out of 7 (since 7 - 3 = 4). So, the ratio of boys to girls is 4:3.

Hence, Statement II alone is sufficient, while Statement I alone is not.

question:
What was the income of the zoo on a certain day?

Statement:

I) 120 persons visited the zoo on that particular day.

II) A discount of 25% was offered on the ticket price on that particular day.

ALP Tier II 21/01/2019 (Evening)
option_1: Neither statementnor II is adequate
option_2: Either statementor II is adequate
option_3: Only statement II while sufficientis not alone
option_4: statementalone is sufficient whereas II is not alone
solution:
Statement I tells us 120 persons visited the zoo, but does not mention ticket price, so income cannot be calculated.

Statement II tells us there was a 25 percent discount on ticket price, but does not tell us how many people visited or what the original price was.

Even together, we do not know the original ticket price, so we cannot find total income.

Therefore, the correct answer is: Neither statementnor II is adequate

question:
Is X-5 even? X is a real number.

Statements:

X -15 belongs to integer

2. X -10 is an odd integer

RRB ALP Tier - I 09/08/2018 (Morning)
option_1: Statement 1 alone is sufficient while statement 2 alone is insufficient
option_2: Neither statement 1 nor 2 is sufficient
option_3: Statement 2 alone is sufficient while statement 1 alone is insufficient
option_4: Both statements 1 and 2 are sufficient
solution:
To determine whether X ‚Äì 5 is even, let's evaluate each statement:

‚úÖ Statement 1: X ‚Äì 15 is an integer

  • If X ‚Äì 15 is an integer, then X = integer + 15, which implies X is also an integer.
  • Therefore, X ‚Äì 5 = integer ‚Äì 5 = integer, so X ‚Äì 5 is an integer, but we don‚Äôt know whether it‚Äôs even or odd.

‚û°Ô∏è Not sufficient to determine if X ‚Äì 5 is even.

‚úÖ Statement 2: X ‚Äì 10 is an odd integer

  • Let‚Äôs assume X ‚Äì 10 = odd integer ‚áí X = odd integer + 10
  • So, X ‚Äì 5 = (odd + 10) ‚Äì 5 = odd + 5 = even

‚û°Ô∏è Sufficient to determine X ‚Äì 5 is even.

ü§ù Combining both statements:

  • Statement 2 alone is already sufficient.
  • So, combining both doesn‚Äôt add value.

‚úçÔ∏è Final Answer:

Statement 2 alone is sufficient, but Statement 1 alone is not sufficient.

question:
The trains are very punctual in Malaysia. For a maximum of how long should Mr. Z wait for the train?

Statements:

Mr. Z had reached the railways station at 10 a.m.

2. There is a train at 11 a. m. and the next train is at 12 p.m.

RRB ALP Tier - I 10/08/2018 (Morning)
option_1: Statement 1 alone is sufficient while statement 2 alone is insufficient.
option_2: Both statement 1 and 2 are sufficient.
option_3: Either statement 1 or 2 is sufficient.
option_4: Statement 2 alone is sufficient while 1 alone is insufficient.
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 tells us Mr. Z reached the station at 10 a.m.

Statement 2 tells us the next trains are at 11 a.m. and 12 p.m.

Since the trains are punctual, and Mr. Z arrived at 10 a.m., the earliest train he can take is at 11 a.m.

So, the maximum wait time is from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m., which is 1 hour.

This conclusion needs both statements together.

question:
What is the value of 14$20*8#4 ?

Statements:

$ implies -, * implies +, # implies √∑

2. 14$20*8=25

RRB ALP Tier - I 14/08/2018 (Afternoon)
option_1: Both statements 1 and 2 are sufficient
option_2: Statement 1 alone is sufficient while statement 2 alone is insufficient
option_3: Neither statement 1 or 2 is sufficient
option_4: Statement 2 alone is sufficient while statement 1 alone is insufficient
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 gives the meaning of each symbol, which is necessary to solve the expression.

Using it, the expression becomes 14 minus 20 plus 8 divided by 4, which can be solved step by step.

Statement 2 only gives the value of part of the expression but does not help in solving the full expression.

So, only the first statement is enough.

question:
When did Mr. Y purchase his car?

Statements:

Certainly before 18th August but not before 15th August.

2. Certainly after 16th August but not later than 19s August.

RRB ALP Tier - I 17/08/2018 (Afternoon)
option_1: Both statement 1 and 2 are sufficient
option_2: Either statement 1 or 2 is sufficient
option_3: Statement 2 alone is sufficient while statement 1 alone is insufficient
option_4: Statement 1 alone is sufficient while statement 2 alone is insufficient
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 says the car was bought after or on 15 August but before 18 August, so the possible dates are 15, 16, or 17 August.

Statement 2 says the car was bought after 16 August but on or before 19 August, so the possible dates are 17, 18, or 19 August.

The only common date between both statements is 17 August.

So, both statements together are sufficient to find the exact date.

question:
What day is the 14th of a given month?

Statements:

The last day of the month is Sunday.

2. The fourth Saturday of the month is 25th

RRB ALP Tier - I 20/08/2018 (Afternoon)
option_1: Both statements 1 and 2 are sufficient.
option_2: Either statement 1 or 2 is sufficient.
option_3: Statement 1 alone is sufficient while statement 2 alone is insufficient.
option_4: Statement 2 alone is sufficient while 1 alone is insufficient.
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 2 says the fourth Saturday is on 25th, so the Saturdays in the month are 4th, 11th, 18th, and 25th.

This means 14th falls between 11th and 18th, so it must be a Wednesday.

Statement 1 only tells us the last day is Sunday, which is not enough to find the day of the 14th.

So, only the second statement is sufficient.

Therefore, statement 2 alone is sufficient while statement 1 alone is insufficient.

question:
Find the values of x, y, z from the given statements.

Statements:

I: x + y = 12; x + z = 4

II: x - y = 6

RRB ALP Tier - I 20/08/2018 (Evening)
option_1: Only I is sufficient while II is not
option_2: Both I and II are sufficient
option_3: Only II is sufficient while I is not
option_4: Neither I nor II is sufficient
solution:
Statement I: x + y = 12 x + z = 4 ‚Üí Two equations, three variables ‚Üí Not sufficient to find unique values.

Statement II: x ‚àí y = 6 ‚Üí One equation, two variables ‚Üí Also not sufficient alone.

Combining I and II: From Statement II: x ‚àí y = 6 ‚Üí add to x + y = 12 ‚áí (x ‚àí y) + (x + y) = 6 + 12 = 2x ‚áí 2x = 18 ‚áí x = 9 Then y = 12 ‚àí x = 3 Then z = 4 ‚àí x = ‚àí5 ‚úÖ All three values determined.

Correct answer: (b) Both I and II are sufficient

question:
Four magicians, U, V, W and X, will perform at a theatre on four consecutive days, each on a different day but not in the same order. On which day will W perform?

Statements:

Show starts on the 1st of Feb and X performs on the next day.

2. U doesn't perform on the 3rd of Feb; one of them performs between U and V.

RRB ALP Tier - I 29/08/2018 (Evening)
option_1: 1 alone is sufficient while 2 alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: Both 1 and 2 together are sufficient to answer the question.
option_3: Either 1 or 2 is sufficient to answer the question.
option_4: 2 alone is sufficient while 1 alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 tells us the show starts on 1st February and X performs on the 2nd. This gives a fixed start point but not enough to find W's exact day.

Statement 2 tells us U does not perform on 3rd February and there is exactly one magician between U and V. Alone, this also does not fix W‚Äôs position.

But when both statements are combined, we can arrange all four performers in a sequence across the four days and determine exactly when W performs.

So, both statements together are sufficient.

question:
How is CHINA coded?

Statements:

CHILE is coded as ECIHL.

2. EGYPT is coded as TEYGP.

RRB ALP Tier - I 30/08/2018 (Evening)
option_1: Both 1 and 2 together are sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: 2 alone is sufficient while 1 alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_3: Either 1 or 2 is sufficient to answer the question.
option_4: 1 alone is sufficient while 2 alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 shows that CHILE is coded as ECIHL. By observing the pattern, the positions of the letters are rearranged in a specific way.

Statement 2 shows a similar pattern in coding EGYPT as TEYGP.

In both cases, a consistent rearrangement logic is applied.

So, using either one of the statements, the same pattern can be identified and used to code CHINA.

Hence, either statement alone is sufficient.

question:
How is P related to C?

Statements:

I. H is the only brother of S and P.

II. P is the wife of L, who is the son-in-law of D

III. D is the mother of S and T is the son-in-law of C

Level 3 (14/06/2022) Shift 1
option_1: Data in Statements I, II and III together are not sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: Data in Statements II and III together are sufficient to answer the question.
option_3: Data in Statements I, II and III together are sufficient to answer the question.
option_4: Data in Statements I alone is sufficient to answer the question.
solution:
Explanation:

Statement I tells us about the sibling relationship among H, S, and P but gives no link to C.

Statement II connects P with L and D, but still does not mention or link C directly.

Statement III tells us about D being S‚Äôs mother and T being C‚Äôs son-in-law, but no connection is made between P and C.

Even after combining all three statements, there is no clear relation established between P and C.

So, the data is not sufficient.

Therefore, Data in Statements I, II and III together are not sufficient to answer the question.

question:
What is the average daily wage of X, Y and Z?

Statements:

Y's salary is half of (X+Z)

2. X and Y together earn ‚Çπ 40 more than Z and Z earns ‚Çπ 500

RRB ALP 09/08/2018 (Evening)
option_1: 2 alone is sufficient while 1 alone is insufficient
option_2: 1 alone is sufficient while 2 alone is insufficient
option_3: Both 1 and 2 are sufficient
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2 is sufficient
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 gives only a ratio relation between Y, X, and Z but does not provide any actual value, so we cannot calculate the average.

Statement 2 provides a definite value: Z earns 500, and X and Y together earn 40 more than Z, so their combined income is 540.

Total income of X, Y, and Z becomes 540 plus 500, which is 1040.

Average daily wage is total divided by three, which gives a definite answer.

So only statement 2 is sufficient.

question:
Who among P, Q, R, S and T is lightest in weight?

Statements:

Q weight < P and S also S weight > T

2. R weight > Q but < T

RRB ALP 09/08/2018 (Afternoon)
option_1: Neither statement 1 nor 2 is sufficient
option_2: Statement 2 alone is sufficient while statement 1 alone is insufficient
option_3: Statement 1 alone is sufficient while statement 2 alone is insufficient
option_4: Both statement 1 and 2 are sufficient
solution:
Explanation:

From Statement 1:

Q is lighter than P, and S is heavier than T. So we get a partial order: Q < P and T < S

From Statement 2:

R is heavier than Q but lighter than T, giving Q < R < T

Combining both statements:

Q < R < T < S and Q < P

Now Q is lighter than P, R, T, and S. Hence, Q is the lightest.

Therefore, both statements together are sufficient.

question:
Who is the shortest among Shamita, Tanya and Rekha?

Statements:

I. Shamita is taller than Rekha. Rekha is shorter than Tanya.

II. Rekha is shorter than Surbhi. Surbhi is taller than Shamita. Tanya is shorter than Surbhi.

A. Statement I alone is sufficient to answer the question. whereas statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.

B. Statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question, whereas statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.

C. Both statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question.

D. Both statements I and II together are necessary to answer the question.

Level 3 (17/06/2022) Shift 3
option_1: C
option_2: A
option_3: D
option_4: B
solution:
Explanation:

Statement I says Shamita is taller than Rekha and Rekha is shorter than Tanya.

So, we get the order: Shamita > Tanya > Rekha or Shamita > Rekha < Tanya

This clearly shows Rekha is the shortest among the three.

Statement II includes Surbhi, who is not part of the question, and gives relative heights involving her.

But it does not help directly compare Shamita, Tanya, and Rekha completely.

So, only statement I is sufficient.

question:
On which date is Evanshu‚Äôs birthday?

Statements:

1: Evanshu‚Äôs birthday is on the Republic day of a country.

2: The country‚Äôs national flag is a tricolour flag with an Ashoka Chakra in its centre.

RRB NTPC 08/01/2021 (Morning)
option_1: Both statements 1 and 2 are sufficient independently.
option_2: Both statements 1 and 2 are sufficient together.
option_3: Statement 1 is sufficient but statement 2 is not sufficient.
option_4: Statement 2 is sufficient but statement 1 is not sufficient.
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 says Evanshu‚Äôs birthday is on the Republic Day of a country, but it does not specify which country. Many countries have different Republic Days, so this alone is not enough.

Statement 2 identifies the country as India by describing the national flag as a tricolour with the Ashoka Chakra. But this alone does not give a date.

When both statements are combined, we know the country is India and its Republic Day is on 26 January. So, Evanshu‚Äôs birthday is on 26 January.

Therefore, both statements together are necessary and sufficient.

question:
Who is the father of M?

Statements:

P and Q are brothers.

2. Q‚Äôs wife is the sister of M‚Äôs wife.

RRB NTPC 29/01/2021 (Evening)
option_1: Statement I and II both are necessary
option_2: Statement I and II both are not sufficient.
option_3: Statement II alone is sufficient.
option_4: Statement I alone is sufficient.
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 tells us that P and Q are brothers, but it gives no information about M or M‚Äôs father.

Statement 2 says Q‚Äôs wife is the sister of M‚Äôs wife, which gives information about the wives' relationship but nothing about M‚Äôs father.

Even when combining both statements, there is no connection between M and any possible father figure.

Therefore, we cannot determine who M‚Äôs father is, even after using both statements together.

question:
Is Raju fond of travelling?

Statements:

Raju has seen East, West, North and Southern parts of India.

2. Raju likes to be in the company of his friends.

RRB ALP 09/08/2018 (Morning)
option_1: Statement 1 alone is sufficient but statement 2 alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: Both statements taken together are sufficient to answer the question, but Neither statement alone is sufficient.
option_3: Statements 1 and 2 together are not sufficient, and additional data is needed to answer the question.
option_4: Statement 2 alone is sufficient but statement 1 alone is not sufficient to answer the Question.
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 tells us that Raju has seen all parts of India, but it doesn‚Äôt confirm whether he enjoys traveling. He might have traveled for work or other reasons.

Statement 2 tells us that Raju enjoys being with friends, which is unrelated to whether he likes traveling.

Even together, these statements do not clearly answer whether Raju is fond of traveling, because behavior does not always reflect preference.

So, more specific information is needed.

question:
Between X and Y who is the better dancer?

Statements:

X had given more dance auditions.

2. Y had given more stage performances.

RRB ALP 09/08/2018 (Morning)
option_1: Neither statement 1 nor 2 is sufficient
option_2: Statement 2 alone is sufficient while statement 1 alone is insufficient
option_3: Statement 1 alone is sufficient while statement 2 alone is insufficient
option_4: Both statement 1 and 2 are sufficient
solution:
Explanation:

Statement 1 says X gave more auditions, but auditions do not prove skill or success in dancing. It only shows effort or interest.

Statement 2 says Y gave more stage performances, which suggests experience, but again does not guarantee that Y is a better dancer.

Neither statement directly compares skill or quality of dancing between X and Y. So, we cannot decide who is better.

Hence, both statements are insufficient.
